text: when the same-sex marriage bill passed
on Friday it was with the support from a
key group of backers on Wall Street
hello Evelyn Rusli with DealBook for the
New York Times joined today with Michael
Barbara one of my colleagues at the
paper thanks so much for joining thank
you for having me so you heard about the
backroom dealings on how this bill got
past who are some of the people in Wall
Street who helped out what's interesting
there were three Wall Street hedge fund
guys three very exceedingly wealthy
hedge-fund guys big donors for the
Republican Party who were very integral
to this process cliff asness of AQR
Capital Management Paul singer of course
of Elliott Elliott management has a be
behind his name billionaire and dan loeb
of Third Point and these three guys had
both a political and a very personal
attachment to the issue of same-sex
marriage let's start with a personal
because it's kind of fascinating Paul
singer is a very conservative guy he's
head of the Manhattan Institute which is
a very conservative think tank in
Manhattan but he has a gay son that gay
son was married in Massachusetts he
believes in this personally as well as
politically the other two guys as well
as mr. singer view this as the ultimate
conservative position limited government
personal freedom same-sex marriage while
it's thought of as a predominantly
democratic liberal issue is viewed by
these guys through the prism of get the
government out of people's bedrooms so
they decide the libertarian kind of
libertarian not necessarily left or
right that's right now how did they all
get involved and I heard that the
governor was very instrumental bringing
them together and and why was he so key
on I'm having these three hedge fund
guys well this is an interesting
backstory these three guys in we're
actually looking to put their money into
it and they were skeptical of whether or
not this Democratic governor could get
it done it was a fascinating secret
meeting a few weeks ago at the office of
Paul singer in Midtown on Fifth Avenue
where two of the governor's top advisors
went and you can only imagine how wild
this was the aides to one of them US
Senate Democratic governors in the
country meeting with these big donors to
the opposing party saying help us get
gay marriage done and by the end of that
meeting it seemed
these guys were believers that homo
could get it done and the reason why the
governor staff wanted them there was
because it was only Republicans with
Republican credentials and Republican
you know a conservative checkbook that
could persuade republican state senators
who were so crucial that actually there
might be an upside to moaning for gay
marriage rather than the downside they
were hearing about from some of their
constituents how instrumental were these
three hedge fund managers to helping
this bill get past I mean can you you
can quantify that it's difficult to
quantify it's a little bit of an
intangible but it's worth going back to
something that Daniel Loeb said to the
New York Times several weeks ago and it
was that if republican state senators
voted for this not only would they not
be abandoned by their Republican base
but a whole new world of donors would be
available to them I'm going to tell you
something that's not such a big secret
in politics money really matters and the
idea that republican state senators were
going to be tapping into this whole new
universe of potential donors was
extremely appealing so while it's
intangible I think we know that it's
something that the governor of New York
would not want it to have you know gone
through without he wanted this support
and he wanted these huge big names on
Wall Street to be there with him trying
to get marriage passed yeah I'll be
interesting to see whether this can be
replicated in other sectors to whether
this kind of coalition will also form
thanks again today my guest has been
Michael Barbara and he's a reporter at
The New York Times and I'm Evelyn Rusli
with DealBook for the New York Times
